title: Doctors were about to pronounce a cyclist dead but then a medic had one final idea
text:

In her own words, Mary describes the day that changed her life forever...

I used to be a bit of an action woman.

I would try my hand at anything, from motorbiking to white-water rafting.

But cycling was my real passion.

As a member of a cycling club I went out with my husband Denis several times a week, covering at least 150 miles.

In 2009, we’d been to France to cycle and watch the Tour de France, and we’d had such a good time.

Since I’d retired from the police, we’d wanted to do more cycling holidays.

But those plans changed on 28 October.

My husband and I had driven from our home in St Helens to Chester to meet up with cycling club friends.

It was a lovely dry morning and we were looking forward to a full day on the bikes.

We parked our car, checked our bikes and set off.

But we had only travelled a few yards when a seven-and-a-half ton lorry came up behind us.

Denis was hit first as he was behind me.

Then he hurtled into me and the lorry hit me too.

My husband was thrown onto the grass verge, suffering a broken pelvis and internal injuries.

I was thrown 10 feet into the air and landed straight onto my legs.

I remember landing and shouting, ‘Help me, help me!’, then nothing.

I suffered a smashed pelvis, four broken vertebrae, broken ribs, a broken knee, and a large cut on the back of my head.

I was rushed to the Countess Of Chester Hospital where I was losing such a massive amount of blood that Manchester Blood Unit had to be contacted to keep supplies going.

My son Philip was teaching in Liverpool when he got the call to come to the hospital urgently, and was asked, ‘Do you want a police escort?’

Philip was faced with the prospect of losing both me and his dad in one fell swoop.

Early on, he was told not to expect me to live.

During my operation, half of the team didn’t think they could do any more for me and wanted to stop.

But one surgeon, Mr Dimitri – who was not on call, but had gone in to see

a patient, heard a serious accident had occurred and had come to A&E to see if he could help – said he ‘just wanted to try one more thing’ to stem the blood loss.

And that’s why I’m still here – it proved to be a life-saving decision.

They used something called a filter to stop the blood, and I was fitted with a metal cage screwed into my bones to help my pelvis knit back together.

Then I was put on life support for two and a half weeks, and was unconscious with no brain activity.

But I’m obviously built of stern stuff, and I regained consciousness.

I was fitted with a back brace and neck brace, but I was devastated when I realised what I could and couldn’t do.

To be honest, I’m still devastated now by my limitations, because of the active life I used to lead.

But I’m here.

Before I left the hospital I asked to speak to the surgeon, and he came to see me for a matter of minutes.

I was very emotional meeting him, very tearful.

I said, ‘What can I say other than thank you.’

I mean, what do you say to someone who has literally saved your life?

He was very matter of fact and played down his part, replying simply that he was doing his job.

It was as straightforward as that, to him.

But he wasn’t going to say he was the most wonderful person ever, even though he was to me.

Him doing his job is very different to someone else doing theirs – he gave me the chance to do all the things I can do today.

He gave me back the chance to have a life, despite my injuries.

My injuries are still extensive.

My pelvis is twisted, and because of extensive nerve damage, my right leg feels like a heavy weight, as though I have pins and needles constantly and my foot is about to explode.

Also, because of the nerve damage I need an insole with a foot brace attached, called a ‘toe off’, which fits into my shoe under my foot and up my leg to try to prevent me from tripping over.

My hearing on the right side is affected, and I take morphine every day to relieve the pain.

I wasn’t expected to live, but I did.

I wasn’t expected to get out of the bed, but I did.

I wasn’t expected to walk, but I did.

Well, I call it walking, although it takes a great effort to go a short distance, and I have to rely on my crutches.

I remember crying a lot when I first realised how badly I’d been hurt and how much my life would change.

But when I came out of hospital five months after the accident, I had a decision to make – sit in a wheelchair and watch the world go by, or go out into the world and get on with my life.

It was a miracle I still had one, so my choice was clear.

I started off slowly with physiotherapy, walking with a tall frame that I clung onto, then returned to the gym, which has helped tremendously.

I’ve fallen several times since the accident, because my pelvis is so weak and I struggle to balance.

I have to use two elbow crutches to walk.

This means that during my long recovery I’ve suffered a broken wrist, a snapped tendon in my thumb, a broken knee and femur and broken ribs.

But they are obstacles and I get over them.

I attended a Fall Prevention class run by the council’s Healthy Living Team, and started exercising using special cycles for disabled people (see right). It’s great going downhill, but not so much coming back up!

I even have a new ‘grandson’ who I ride with – a 30-year-old man who is autistic and seems to have adopted me.

We have lots of fun, and I love our new relationship.

I have the greatest praise for our wonderful NHS.

Without the paramedics in the first instance and then the doctors, surgeons and nurses, I would not be here today – although I’m trying to keep away from their services now!

And, because I’m a Christian, I have been able to take an extremely positive approach in my disability.

Of course I have my down days.

Denis and I used to walk everywhere holding hands, ever since we were courting, and now we can’t do that because of my crutches.

That upsets me.

And when my granddaughter, Rebecca, first started walking I desperately wanted to play Ring O’Roses with her, but couldn’t.

It’s strange how things that seem so trivial can cause so much hurt.

But I have to be positive.

I might not have the retirement I’d planned with Denis, but I’m still here with him.

And Rebecca is 10 years old now and my absolute sunshine.

I am very fortunate I’m able to watch her grow up.

I get sad that I can’t just go out for a long walk on a beautiful day, but I’m never angry or bitter.

I just try to live the best life I can.

I do think about the fact I might not have been here if it wasn’t for the quick thinking of one surgeon, and it’s humbling.

When I’m with my family it puts everything into perspective, all that I might have missed out on, so whatever pain I’m in, whatever I go through, it makes life worth living.

And it’s better than the alternative – I don’t like pine!
description: Mary Ellison suffered awful injuries when was knocked off her bike and taken to the Countess Of Chester  - she wasn’t expected to live but then an off duty surgeon came up with an idea
